title: Risotto ai Funghi
description: Creamy Italian risotto studded with earthy mushrooms, finished with butter and Parmesan for a silky texture. Slow-simmered arborio rice absorbs a warm mushroom and white wine broth for deep, savory flavor.

ingredients.display_name: mixed mushrooms (cremini + shiitake), cleaned and sliced
ingredients.notes: trim stems, slice thicker varieties into even pieces
keep at a gentle simmer in a separate pan
such as pinot grigio or sauvignon blanc
divided: for cooking mushrooms and finishing
or 1 small yellow onion, finely chopped
adjust to taste; reserve some for finishing

steps.text: Prepare: bring vegetable stock to a gentle simmer in a saucepan and keep hot over low heat; clean and slice mushrooms, finely dice onion, and mince garlic.

Sear mushrooms: heat 1 tablespoon butter and 1 tablespoon olive oil in a large wide sautée pan over medium-high heat; add mushrooms in a single layer, season with a pinch of salt, and cook without stirring until golden on one side, then stir and continue until deeply browned; transfer mushrooms to a bowl and set aside.
Sweat aromatics: reduce heat to medium, add remaining olive oil to the pan, add diced onion and a pinch of salt, sweat until translucent but not browned; add garlic and thyme and cook until fragrant.
Toast rice: add arborio rice to the aromatics, stir to coat grains with fat, and toast for 1–2 minutes until edges look translucent and rice smells nutty.
Deglaze with wine: pour in the white wine, increase heat slightly, and stir until the wine is mostly absorbed.

Add stock gradually: add a ladle (about 120 ml) of hot stock to the rice and stir until mostly absorbed; continue adding stock one ladle at a time, stirring frequently and allowing each addition to be absorbed before adding the next, maintaining a gentle simmer.
Return mushrooms: when the rice is just tender with a slight al dente center (after most stock used), stir the reserved mushrooms into the rice to reheat and distribute flavors.

Finish with butter and cheese: remove pan from heat, stir in remaining butter and grated Parmigiano-Reggiano vigorously to emulsify and create a creamy finish; season to taste with salt, pepper, and optional lemon zest.
Rest and serve: let risotto rest for 1–2 minutes off heat to settle, then spoon into warm bowls, garnish with chopped parsley and an extra grating of Parmesan, and serve immediately.
